content: Hello hello
Hey now
hey
So it sounds like we're all in agreement all of these formats are for documentation
is that right?
(jumping right in)
definitely the motivating factor I've seen
yes, documentation
docs is number one reason for creating API definition in my world, ultimately so I can communicate what the interface is to others
@kinlane until now many APIs have just had help pages
So no google hangouts for now?
@kinlane like Yahoo for example
Just wanted to make sure there aren't two of these rooms
@usarid I could do a hangout as well.
Doesn't matter to me, just don't want to miss out on the fun if there are two of these locations now
want me to start hangout?
@usarid Aaah so there is a hangout?
no hangout for me... but dont let me stop you
I was starting but glenn kicked this off
@kinlane this has some longevity beyond a hangout
too much democracy! :-)
@usarid ha ha
here we are chat is good.
@kinlane but it doesn't have the level of interaction
agreed
@kinlane I figured we'd setup a hangout in the future so whoever wants to join can do it
sure. I'll help coordinate.
@kinlane have you looked at hydra?
just briefly. Its on my target list to dive in deeper.
Seems similar goals.
So part of my reason for jumping in
is I am exploring the idea of us supporting one or more formats for Splunk's API
good to hear
So started to look around and see what options are available
seem to be let to the party
We use a lot of linking and such in our representations
@gblock - re tools being only for documentation: I think that's a bit narrow
@jakubnesetril well that's why I asked :-)
would you agree its the #1 reason people are paying attention to API definitions?
@jakubnesetril I will be forthright and reveal a negative bias against tooling for the client, BUT that's based on my experience with the existing tools.

one of the things that devs hate doing is maintaining multiple versions of truth… one is the code, another is the spec… there needs to be some mechanism to keep that in sync… some tools prefer codegen from the spec, others keep the spec inside code…
@jakubnesetril and the lack of evolvability inherently built in the code they spit out.
even though there are many more tooling opportunities
yeah, agreed -- with a good spec you can document, you can test, you can model usecases, you can create consoles, you can ...
I think that the spec should be thought of as a form of contract and treated as any other test in your test suite… so it should be part of your continuous integration…
@jakubnesetril agreed.

that's a way to keeping the multiple versions of truth synchronized without tying code to spec; which I think should be separate - just as generating code from your test suite or vice versa would defeat the point
@jakub ok so you are thinking of this from a verification perspective?
@jakub I agree on the single source of truth aspect.
oops that was meant for @jakubnesetril

@gblock depends on the specific team how far they want to take this… but producing documentation that requires continuous maintenance without some automated check is very error-prone… and the documentation being up-to-date/accurate is very important to the overall usage experience
@jakubnesetril I like the thinking there. Using the spec for verification that the API behaves as it should makes a lot of sense.
@jakubnesetril I don't disagree with that

@gblock also following up on previous discussion wrt versioning: the blueprint/raml/swagger's of the world should be versioned alongside code… and I don't mean specific version identifiers in the API/specification (that can happen too) but I mean the document file physically living in your code repository next to your code
@jakubnesetril agreed. It's an artifact though not necessarily bound to a specific implementation.

that way it's easy to keep the contract in sync between various branches/revisions, in a standard code lifecycle process… if you're releasing a new version -> merging a different branch to master/trunk -> merging the documentation & contract & test suite alongside with it
@jakubnesetril define what you mean by version
@jakubnesetril is that version of the codebase, version of the API ?

@jakubnesetril I would watch out though for what@gblock mentioned -- be careful not to tie your implementation to your API in that the version of the API needs to be managed more carefully IMHO than the code version

@gblock keeping it loose on purpose… some people "version" non-desctrutively by evolving the API and/or namespacing… some people prefer to create explicit API versions and declare them… all of this however should follow the same development/merging/deployment lifecycle as code does
@usarid right. I agree the document should be versioned, and each release should get associated to say that this supports this version of the doc.
@jakubnesetril I think there's no doubt that the codebase is tied to some version of the document in this world.
@jakubnesetril though the reverse is not the case, meaning the document could apply to different implementations.

@jakubnesetril I agree with you that there are different versioning strategies. Personally I am fan of the evolvable API, but that doesn't change the fact that most of the world today does not do that.

The API spec occupies a special place: it's the contract, as several of us have stated many times, so you need to find a way to arrange your code and lifecycle such that you know what API you need to support over what period of time
@usarid yes

@gblock same here… but API blueprint supports all of these scenarios on purpose… at the end of the day, for public APIs you usually have an endpoint/server where you promise an API to live. The public documentation describes how you expect that endpoint to work, so that documentation should be in sync with the code powering that API. But you could see a higher level way of looking at things.
How about adopting http://semver.org/ -- what are your thoughts, folks?
@usarid and I really like the idea of having some sort of verification tool chain around it. I wasn't thinking of tat before.
Not as a mandate but as a best practice?
i like the idea of a verification toolchain...

@usarid yes… however keeping the spec accurate as there are ad-hoc changes/fixes made to the code is usually the bigger challenge over the long run, rather producing code that matches initial spec design
@usarid I can imagine products/frameworks popping up where you run it on your CI
@usarid and it just validates that the API works as it should. The devil is always in the details though.
spec defines requirements, developer creates API, API generates documentation need tool to compare actual (generated documentation) to expected (spec)
@gblock we provide http://github.com/apiaryio/dredd for API blueprint… MIT'ed (as all of our OSS tools)
more sophisticated than that,but i like the concept
@gblock (I meant to say for testing API blueprint in your CI)
To throw another option in the mix, are you all aware of ALPS? http://amundsen.com/hypermedia/profiles/
@gblock indeed they are popping up, and a few more will popup soon, some as downloadable OSS libraries, others as SaaS offerings
@jakubnesetril - you work at apiary?
and all of them probably depending on, or at least benefiting from, a contract against which to test -- the API spec
@jakubnesetril DREDD looks cool. Did not know about it.
@robbinhun yessir, I founded it
@jakubnesetril good job :-)

More info here: http://blog.apiary.io/2013/10/17/How-to-test-api-with-api-blueprint-and-dredd/ Dredd works with several Continuous Integration Services. I’ve tested it with Travis-CI, Circle-CI, Codeship, Semaphore, Teamcity, Jenkins, Atlassian Bamboo and probably many others.
@jakubnesetril having a way to verify your API works as it should without having to create a zillion tests manually sounds like goodness to me.
@jakubnesetril the one pushback would be lock-in. Once I go down this path I am tied to your solution.
yeah, i'm still in "write integration tests to the spec" land
@gblock nope… the core (language, parser, compiler) are all OSS'ed (with MIT license) and there is a growing community of 3rd-party tools, including documentation rendered etc…
@gblock, with any solution like that i think vendor lock-in is inevitable, so hard to get competitors to agree on open standards (typically)
@jakupnesetril -- does blueprint have anything like "Traits" for RAML?
@gblock we even launched http://apiblueprint.org/ to promote the language as open and not locked into us…
in defining the api spec that is
@jakubnesetril OK it's OSS, but I mean you get tied completely to the format. But that is inevitable.
@jakubnesetril fair enough, vendor maybe was not the proper word.
@gblock well, you can always use the parser and just translate this to other formats
@jakubnesetril I am not saying it's bad. Look we make choices.
@jakubnesetril and though it's nice to always be able to pick up and move to something else, the reality is to take deep advantage of anything, you take a dependency.
@jakubnesetril Or you take a dependency on some abstract-weakest-common-denominator sort of thing which sucks
@jakubnesetril for lack of a better word.

@gblock sure, I just want to list the options… once the underlying toolchain is open/public, you can migrate to/from formats as necessary… while we think Blueprint is great (obviously) we try to play nice and not lock people in…
@jakubnesetril that's great to hear.
@robbihun @gblock @jakubnesetril there is no MOAS (Mother Of All Specs) yet!
@jakubnesetril Personally I think the winners will be by natural selection. Each format focusing on what it does best.
@usarid Let's hope vendors are not listening ;-)
hah, hope they are actuall
@robbihun ok scheming
Wait, a couple of us *are* vendors!
@usarid ok listen, yes don't dominate.
But fortunately the formats, and our tooling, is all free
@usarid says the guy who left a very large vendor recently.

@robbinhun re: traits - that's where RAML is indeed very nice… and it's appropriate for it to be, since it's focused on modeling… we're more focusing on keeping the spec simple, human-readable/writable and integrated with documentation… so we're still looking at how to support some inheritance/traits while keeping it very simple & human-friendly
@jakubnesetril I applaud that. I feel the same with swagger.
@jakubnesetril -- you guys manage that, and it makes the decision really hard
@jakubnesetril but the world is a big place with room for more than one solution.
hey @jakubnesetril you no think traits and types make a spec more readable?
i feel in my blueprints i'm copying pasting code for api headers/request params, etc... but it gives me the mocks and testing...
@jakubnesetril Yeah you nailed where my concern is when I saw RAML.
raml lets my handwritten docs be DRY, but no automation or mocking (yet)
see, i think raml is very concise and readable
@robbihun did you try the new blueprint? it has inheritance support for heads/params inside documentation groups…
@robbihun mocking is in alpha now (I can give you a demo) and test automation is coming, fer sure important
hah, no on both accounts... just playing with what is out there for both blueprint and raml
i like both of them, really do
(thumbs up) glad to hear
but neither are the tool that @gblock is looking for

One way or another, guys, we're all going to want to avoid repeating ourselves, so we'll need to have some mechanism for pointing to something and saying: just like that, just like that, etc. We call them traits and types, and hopefully blueprint will have something like that too
@robbihun at the risk of being ignorant - so what is @gblock looking for again?
@usarid I agree DRY is a good thing.
@jakubnesetril now I am curious what @robbihun thinks I am looking for. ;-)
All of this started prompted by an article from @kinlane talking about standardization in open gov APIs
I was *wondering* what started this twitter torrent
sounds to me like @gblock is looking for an end-to-end toolchain requirements end up also being used to generate tests to verify
as well as create docs
@jakubnesetril and he mentioned swagger, blueprints and RAML
https://gist.github.com/robbihun/3e7f967785fbd8c0475b (my raml, i created last night when i learned about raml, i think it's very readable in this format)
oh, sorry, too much
ouch
@jakubnesetril Aargh, my eyes, my eyes!
@jakubnesetril anyway, I work at Splunk on our developer experience. I have also been pretty involved in the API space
@jakubnesetril in particular from the dev experience angle
@jakubnesetril and at Splunk I drive our client SDKs which consume Splunk's API in many diff languages
@jakubnesetril anyway, after Kin's article, I thought to myself it's worth checking out the diff formats to see the progress around API documentation etc
@gblock that developer experience is key, good to know!
@jakubnesetril and then I jumped into looking at the 3 and shared initial impressions on twitter
We were big splunk consumers at my last company (B&N) and the developer/operator UI was key to why we kept piling on more and more uses of it -- not at the API but the actual product
@gblock very cool, I love Splunk! We should catch up for a coffee if your in Bay Area anytime
@jakubnesetril Hypermedia is also something that I am a big fan of / proponent of
@jakubnesetril sweet. I'll be in town in a few weeks
@gblock ping me too, would love to meet up in person in SF
@jakubnesetril so one thing I was looking at is what kind of support these different formats have for expressing Hypermedia
@jakubnesetril it seems like Swagger has kind of punted on it for now based on it not being mature enough.
@jakubnesetril as a practice
anyway....that kind of give the context?
@usarid good to know!

@gblock we're looking at how to help; the hypermedia community itself needs to find out where this will go… there is a rather is a very long and interesting thread about it here https://github.com/apiaryio/api-blueprint/issues/13
@gblock hypermedia has been a bit of a vacuum in this space, I think
@jakubnesetril wow that is quite the thread.
@usarid I think it's still young and misunderstood.
API design + hypermedia are two areas I'm dedicating more storytelling time on in 2014. Time is ripe.
@usarid other than the browser which just works whether you understand hypermedia or not :-)
@kinlane totally agree.
@kinlane As an example, when I was at Microsoft
@gblock it's like all teenagers: young, misunderstood, shows a lot of promise, and everybody wonders if this year is when they finally grow up :D
@kinlane we worked with Office Lync and they built their new API for millions of mobile and web clients which is hypermedia based
@kinlane and this includes those small little phones we carry around
@jakubnesetril ha ha!
i havn't been sold on hypermedia yet, one problem is i cant get a single consistent definition on "how" it should work from anyone...
@robbihun same is true for rest though ;)
@jakubnesetril education on value is a challenge
@jakubnesetril and not being dogmatic in the process
@gblock I agree, very much
@jakubnesetril - fair enough
It's one of the goals in our new book (shameless plug) http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920026617.do
To try to show people what it is and how it can work

That's one of the reasons why it's so powerful. If it's a philosophy rather then specification (as Hypermedia and REST both are) then it's open to interpretation, evolution etc. It makes coding along that philosophy harder, but it leaves it flexible to change…
@jakubnesetril hypermedia is definitely not a specification
Beats premature standardization by W3C in my view, as evidenced by WS-*
@jakubnesetril though specifications can support it
@gblock exactly, and neither is REST
@jakubnesetril preach brother

We've had enterprise customers and prospects read about how pure hypermedia approaches mean there should be no API contract and tell us emphatically they DO NOT want hypermedia because they DO WANT contracts
@jakubnesetril I've tried to drop just using the word REST since it's completely misunderstood
@gblock ditto
@jakubnesetril we barely mention it in the book for that reason
@gblock same here
@jakubnesetril what kind of system are you building? what are your constraints, etc
@jakubnesetril but Hypermedia != REST
it's an API, i've made decisions on how things work, what a resource is... a lot of it may look like "REST" but it's not a religous argument, it's a product that actually ships
@jakubnesetril and that is something people have to really learn / we need to be better at telling
i'm interested
@gblock sure, didn't equate those to, just thought they both share the "idea > standardization" approach
@jakubnesetril which is why it's important to me that formats at least support it so that we can start to tell that story
@jakubnesetril I wasn't trying to educate you, but many people try to equate them
@gblock agreed
@jakubnesetril just like they equate REST == HTTP
@jakubnesetril Hypermedia still has a hope in that many don't understand it, but it hasn't become a "pop culture" term
@gblock what would support look like?
@jakubnesetril at least yet....
@usarid Allowing me to express in documentation the presence of links
@usarid and possibly forms
For example, the ability to reference resources so the payload media type of your choice can refer to them?
@usarid forms not in the HTML sense, but a form never the less. Something that i can use to transition the state of the app

@gblock it is too complicated to become pop culture… currently the hope is that proper tooling is going to solve that, but I'm skeptical at hiding/masking over complexity with tooling… we'll see though
@jakubnesetril you and I are on the same page. It NEVER works
Usually the media type you've chosen to use in your API will specify the link semantics, etc, right?
@jakubnesetril it works sometimes to get started but you inevitably end up hitting a brick wall
@usarid yes media type or profile
@usarid you know about profile?
Yes, at least at some level, having gone through some of the proposals
ALPS and HAL and such

@gblock so my intuition for hypermedia would be to start boiling things down to essentials; learning about profiles, media types, relationships..... that's a lot to take in, it's a big stumbling block towards becoming mainstream
@usarid profile is really just a way too layer semantics on an existing media type: https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc6906.txt
@usarid it provides a way out from HAVING to mint a new media type. That's why I like it.
@usarid you don't have to standardize with IANA, but it's still discoverable via the Profile header.
@usarid Well discoverable via a profile link header.
@jakubnesetril it can start as simple as just expressing links
@jakubnesetril it doesn't HAVE to start off so complicated

I'd like to find a way to support hypermedia without mandating them, as sort of an overlay: if your media type is of a hypermedia variety, has links and profiles and such, then the rest of the API spec, say RAML, supports it, e.g. in that it allows you to reference the resources from your hypermedia
@jakubnesetril profile is really free form, there's no "spec". But it seems like each of the formats you guys are working on should be sufficient for expressing a profile no?
@jakubnesetril I mean there's no required format. There is a spec...but you can make it anyway you like.
@usarid +1
@gblock agreed
@usarid I am not at all asking you guys to force it
@gblock I agree, which is why I'm talking about the RAML spec supporting hypermedia in as much of a media type-independent way
@jakubnesetril I am asking for it to be something first class if one wants to use it
@usarid that's great
I totally do not want to see it forced
but lets say someone is trying to build a hypermedia system
hey lets say you are my friend over in Office Lync

github

so i need to read more about hypermedia apis
